data.title: 50 great quotes about acting
data.text:
"Know your lines and don't bump into the furniture"

A line that may have originated with Noel Coward but which is most often attributed to SPENCER TRACY, a true acting great who was noninated for nine Oscars, winning two (above, Tracy in the 1950 film Father Of The Bride, with Joan Bennett).

Culture stars who died in 2016

"I never said all actors are cattle, what I said was all actors should be treated like cattle."

ALFRED HITCHCOCK the acclaimed director of Psycho, The Birds, Vertigo and Rear Window, is photographed on a visit to the set of Coronation Street's pub, The Rovers Return, at Granada television studios in Manchester in June 1964. In response to his comments, actress Carole Lombard once brought some heifers on to the set of the 1941 film Mr and Mrs Smith with name tags of Lombard, Robert Montgomery and Gene Raymond, the stars of the film.

Alfred Hitchcock: sadistic prankster

“Every bad decision I’ve made has been based on money. I grew up in the projects and you don’t turn down money there. You take it, because you never know when it’s all going to end. I made Cop III because they offered me $15 million. That $15 million was worth having Roger Ebert’s thumb up my ass.”

EDDIE MURPHY on the 1994 film Beverly Hills Cop III (above, Murphy with Theresa Randle). Esteemed film critic Ebert once wrote that Murphy had gone from "a smart, funny street cop" in the original film to a "loud, arrogant boor" in the sequels.

"Actors are there to entertain people. We're not up there to feel anything, nobody's interested. Peter O'Toole told me that when yout the script, you just perform as though you were late for a train. Don't get caught 'acting'"

JOHN GOODMAN, above in The Great Lebowski with Jeff Bridges. Goodman, who has also starred in films such as Argo and Raising Arizona, won a Golden Globe best actor award for his work in the comedy series Roseanne.

What it's like to audition for the Coen Brothers

"As an actor you spend all your life trying to do something they put people in asylums for."

JANE FONDA is seen her playing the part of Catherine (Cat) Ballou, who runs into a little trouble in Wolf City, Wyoming. That part came in 1965, before she was the infamous Hanoi Jane and before she won her two Oscars (for Klute in 1971 and Coming Home in 1978).

"It's what I learn from the great actors that I work with. Stillness. That's all and that's the hardest thing."

MORGAN FREEMAN (above in his Oscar-nominated role as Nelson Mandela in the 2009 film Invictus) first took took acting lessons at the Pasadena Playhouse in San Francisco in the early Sixties after spending four years in the United States Air Force. He won an Oscar for Million Dollar Baby.

"The best thing about acting is that I get to lose myself in another character and actually get paid for it... It's a great outlet. I'm not really sure who I am – it seems I change every day."

LEONARDO DICAPRIO first appeared in a film in 1991, when he was 17. He has since been involved with 39 films as an actor and producer. He is up for an Oscar for the sixth time for his role in The Revenant (above).

Robbie Collin reviews The Revenant

"Acting is the perfect idiot's profession... acting is the most minor of gifts and not a very high-class way to earn a living. After all, Shirley Temple could do it at the age of four.”

KATHARINE HEPBURN was 96 when she died in 2003 and was considered one of the true greats of Hollywood's golden age. Hepburn (pictured above in 1932) won four Academy Awards for Best Actress – Morning Glory (1934), Guess Who's Coming to Dinner (1968), The Lion in Winter (1969) and On Golden Pond (1982) – a record for any performer. She was nominated a further eight times.

"Not to sound rude, but [acting] is stupid... Everybody's like, 'How can you remain with a level head?' And I'm like, 'Why would I ever get cocky? I'm not saving anybody's life. There are doctors who save lives and firemen who run into burning buildings. I'm making movies. It's stupid.'"

JENNIFER LAWRENCE (above as X-Men shape-shifting villain Mystique) had won an Academy Award for Best Actress by the age of 22, making her the second-youngest Best Actress Oscar winner ever.

Jennifer Lawrence in pictures

"Acting is the expression of a neurotic impulse. It's a bum's life. The principal benefit acting has afforded me is the money to pay for my psychoanalysis."

MARLON BRANDO, who is said to have perfected the method acting style created b Constantin Stanislavski, won Oscars for his roles as Terry Malloy in On the Waterfront (1954) and Vito Corleone in The Godfather (1972). Brando (above, in 1963 during the filming of Bedtime Story) was also the star of A Streetcar Named Desire (1951), The Wild One (1953) and Apocalypse Now (1979).

"There are two types of actors: those who say they want to be famous and those who are liars."

In case you think of KEVIN BACON as just the advertising figurehead of the EE phone network, or as the commercial spokesperson for the US egg industry, then bring to mind his fine acting career, even if he has never had an Oscar nomination. The star of the 1984 film Footloose (above, playing Ren McCormack, with Lori Singer as Ariel Moore) has won a Golden Globe Award and three Screen Actors Guild Awards. And this son of a teacher and architect, one of six children, did indeed become famous. He also said that “If you’re an actor, even a successful one, you’re still waiting for the phone to ring.”

"I cut tobacco for a living in Kentucky. That was hard work. I sold insurance door-to-door. That's hard work. Acting is not hard work. If you're lucky enough to be sitting at a table like this, you've been very lucky in your life. You caught the brass ring somewhere along the way."

GEORGE CLOONEY, seen here in his latest Coen Brothers film Hail, Caesar!

"Acting is a masochistic form of exhibitionism. It is not quite the occupation of an adult."

SIR LAURENCE OLIVIER (above playing Henry V in the 1946 film) had a father – a clergyman – who was determined his son would become an actor and sent him to drama school at a young age. Olivier, who is honoured in the name of the largest auditorium at the National Theatre, won four Oscars, two Baftas and three Golden Globes. He was born on May 22 1907 and died on 11 July, 1989. His final role was in the 1989 film War Requiem, an adaptation of Benjamin Britten's musical piece, where he simply played 'Old Soldier'.

"Never relax and mean what you say."

JAMES CAGNEY (above, in Angels With Dirty Faces) gives his advice on acting. The former street fighter, who died on March 30, 1986, aged 86, set the standard for gangster roles in the Thirties and won an Academy Award for Yankee Doodle Dandy. In 1974, he became the first actor to receive the Life Achievement Award of the American Film Institute. The actor was self-taught and used the mannerisms of people he had known. He did all his own, sometimes vicious, fight scenes, learning judo for one role. He dismissed Method acting with disdain, saying: "'You don't psych yourself up for these things, you do them. I'm acting for the audience, not for myself, and I do it as directly as I can.''

"Why am I in Jurassic Park III? Because I’m 50 years old and I get to fight a dinosaur.”

WILLIAM H MACY (above in the 2001 film Jurassic Park III with Sam Neill and Téa Leoni) is best known for his Oscar-nominated role in Fargo but has appeared in numerous small, independent films.

“First of all, I choose the great roles, and if none of these come, I choose the mediocre ones, and if they don’t come, I choose the ones that pay the rent.”

MICHAEL CAINE, who is an Oscar winner once said of his role in Jaws: The Revenge (1987) that "I have never seen it, but by all accounts it is terrible. However, I have seen the house that it built, and it is terrific.”

Michael Caine: good and awful, says Robbie Collin

"Acting just happens to be my skill, but I think I would probably be just as happy being a technician or entering into the film business in some other way."

JODIE FOSTER (left in Flight Plan) earned her first Oscar nomination as a young teenager. In more recent years, the star of films such as The Accused and The Silence of the Lambs, has become a respected director on the big and small screen.

"All the world's a stage, And all the men and women merely players; They have their exits and their entrances, And one man in his time plays many parts."

WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE'S famous lines in the 1623 play As You Like It were delivered by the character Jacques (above, being played by James Garnon at London's Globe Theatre in May 2015).

400 years of Shakespeare

"If you really do want to be an actor who can satisfy himself and his audience, you need to be vulnerable."

JACK LEMMON was a master at many roles, including playing the musician Jerry, who has to dress up as Daphne to avoid the mob, in the brilliant 1959 comedy Some Like it Hot. Lemmon was an eight time Oscars nominee, winning twice.

"One thing about being a successful actor is that I stopped being afraid of dying. Once you're a star you're dead already. You're embalmed. "

DUSTIN HOFFMAN launched a briliant career playig a young ex-student who has an affair with one of his parents friends (Anne Bancroft) in the 1967 classic The Graduate.

“An actress can only play a woman. I'm an actor, I can play anything.”

WHOOPI GOLDBERG is seen here reprising her film role as Sister Mary, a lounge bar singer who pretends to be a nun, for the 2010 stage version of Sister Act. Goldberg, a comedian, is one of the few people who have won an Emmy Award, a Grammy, an Oscar and a Tony, and was only the secon black woman in acting to have won an acting Oscar.

"I don't think of myself as a character actress - that's become a phrase which means you've had it."

BETTE DAVIS (above right) was 54 and Joan Crawford was 58 when these two old rivals from the golden age of Hollywood starred in the 1962 thriller What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?

"I'm curious about other people. That's the essence of my acting. I'm interested in what it would be like to be you."

MERYL STREEP is seen here in the 2012 film Hope Springs, in which she plays a woman in need of marriage therapy. Streep, a three-time Oscars winner, is regarded as the finest actress of the modern era.

"The best actors do not let the wheels show."

HENRY FONDA, seen here in his Oscar-nominated role as Tom Joad in the 1940 film version of the John Steinbeck novel The Grapes of Wrath. Fonda was the patriarch of a family of famous actors, including daughter Jane Fonda, son Peter Fonda, grand-daughter Bridget Fonda and grandson Troy Garity. He died onAugust 12, 1982, aged 77.

10 surprising facts about The Grapes of Wrath

“I was a medium-level juvenile delinquent from Newark who always dreamed about doing a movie. Someone said, ‘Hey, here’s $7 million, come in and do this genie movie.’ What am I going to say, no?”

SHAQUILLE O'NEILL, the former basketball star turned actor and rap star, was talking about his 1996 film Kazaam. A year later he was nominated for a worst actor Razzie for his performance in Steel.

"There's nothing more boring than unintelligent actors, because all they have to talk about is themselves and acting. There have to be other things."

TIM ROBBINS (seen here in the 1990 film Jacob's Ladder), is a multi-talented man. As well as being an Oscar-winning actor, he is a screenwriter, director, producer, folk musician and a political activist.

"Actors with political views are a dime a dozen."

TOM HANKS, who has starred in and voiced some of the most popular films in modern times – including Forrest Gump, and the Toy Story series – and his movies have grossed more than six billion dollars. He is seen here as Wilson in Cast Away, talking to his volleyball. Hanks may have been being ironic. He has campaigned for Barack Obama, gay rights and environmental issues.

Tom Hanks is outdated says his son Chester

"When you talk about a great actor, you're not talking about Tom Cruise. His whole behaviour is so shocking. It's inappropriate and vulgar and absolutely unacceptable to use your private life to sell anything commercially, but I think it's kind of a sickness."

LAUREN BACALL'S famously withering verdict on the action star Tom Cruise (seen right in the film Knight and Day) in an interview for Time in 2008. Bacall (far left), who was married to Humphrey Bogart, was named one of the greatest stars of Classic Hollywood cinema by the American Film Institute. She died in 2015, aged 89.

Lauren Bacall in pictures

"To me, acting is the most logical way for people's neuroses to manifest themselves, in this great need we all have to express ourselves."

JAMES DEAN, star of the celebrated 1955 film Rebel Without a Cause, died tragically in the year the film was released aged just 24.

"For an actress to be a success, she must have the face of a Venus, the brains of a Minerva, the grace of Terpsichore, the memory of a MaCaulay, the figure of Juno, and the hide of a rhinoceros."

ETHEL BARRYMORE (1879-1959) was an American actress for six decades and was known as the 'First Lady of American Theatre'. She won an Oscar for her role opposite Cary Grant in None But the Lonely and is pictured here in The Spiral Staircase (above left, with Dorothy McGuire), a 1946 thriller about a serial killer who murders disabled young women.

80 great quotes about love

"I'm not a glamour boy, and I never get the girl. I like to play old people, because there's something to them. Did you ever see anybody under 30 with any real character or expression in his face?"

WALTER BRENNAN was 54 when he played Nadine Groot in Red River (right, with co-star John Wayne). Brennan is one of three men to win three acting Oscars (along with Jack Nicholson and Daniel Day-Lewis). He won three best supporting actor awards for Come and Get Me (1938)m, Kentucky (1940) and The Westerner (1941).

10 surprising facts about John Wayne

"Things with my dad were pretty good until I won an Academy Award. He was really loving to me until I got more attention than he did. Then he hated me."

TATUM O'NEAL may have proved Walter Brennan wrong, because there was enough expression in her face to become the youngest Oscar winner in history, picking up the best supporting actress trophy at the age of 10 for her role as tomboy Addie in Paper Moon (1973). But appearing opposite her father, Ryan O'Neal, doesn't seem to have done either much good in the family stakes.

"An actor is an interpreter of other men's words, often a soul which wishes to reveal itself to the world but dare not, a craftsman, a bag of tricks, a vanity bag, a cool observer of mankind, a child, and at his best a kind of unfrocked priest who, for an hour or two, can call on heaven and hell to mesmerise a group of innocents."

ALEC GUINNESS, seen here in the 1965 film Situation Hopeless but not Serious.

Alec Guinness in films: picture special

“I made some mistakes in drama. I thought the drama was when actors cried. But drama is when the audience cries.”

FRANK CAPRA, who directed the classic Christmas weepie It's a Wonderful Life, starring James Stewart.

"One of the things I like about acting is that, in a funny way, I come back to myself."

BILL MURRAY, seen here in Groundhog Day.

Eight brilliant true Bill Murray stories

“Acting is a question of absorbing other people's personalities and adding some of your own experience.”

PAUL NEWMAN, whose character Lucas Jackson has to absorb 50 hard-boiled eggs in the film Cool Hand Luke.

“The play was a great success, but the audience was a disaster.”

A quote attributed to OSCAR WILDE about a production of his play Lady Windermere's Fan (although not the 2002 one here with Vanessa Redgrave and Joely Richardson).

"Almost anyone can give a good representative performance when you're unknown. It's just easier. The real pro game of acting is after you're known—to 'un-Jack' that character, in my case, and get the audience to reinvest in a new and specific, fictional person."

JACK NICHOLSON had been nominated for four Oscars before finally winning for his role as Randolph P McMurphy in One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest.

"Hi-Diddle-Dee-Dee.

An actor's life for me.

A high silk hat, and a silver cane.

A watch of gold, with a diamond chain.

Hi-Diddle-Dee-Day,

an actor's life is gay!

It's great to be a celebrity.

An actor's life for me!"

The song that Honest John sings in PINOCCHIO. The tune is used throughout the 1940 Walt Disney film to represent temptation.

Gallery compiled by Martin Chilton
